\omega & \mapsto*\omega:=\frac{1}{\left(n-k\right)!}\varepsilon_{\phantom{i_{1}\ldots i_{k}}i_{k+1}\ldots i_{n}}^{i_{1}\ldots i_{k}}\omega_{i_{1}\ldots i_{k}}\dd x^{i_{k+1}}\wedge\ldots\wedge\dd x^{i_{n}}
\end{align*}
Dabei ist $\varepsilon_{\phantom{i_{1}\ldots i_{k}}i_{k+1}\ldots i_{n}}^{i_{1}\ldots i_{k}}=g^{i_{1}j_{1}}\ldots g^{i_{k}j_{k}}\varepsilon_{j_{1}\ldots j_{k},i_{k+1}\ldots i_{n}}$.
Also ist $*\omega$ ein $\left(0,n-k\right)$-Tensor.


\subsection{Satz}

Es gilt:
\begin{align*}
*^{2} & =\left(-1\right)^{k\left(n-k\right)}\mathbbm{1}_{\Omega^{k}\left(M\right)}=\begin{cases}
\mathbbm{1}_{\Omega^{k}\left(M\right)} & \text{falls }n\text{ ungerade}\\
\left(-1\right)^{k}\mathbbm{1}_{\Omega^{k}\left(M\right)} & \text{falls }n\text{ gerade}
\end{cases}
\end{align*}



\subsubsection*{Beweis}

\begin{align*}
**\omega & =\frac{1}{k!\left(n-k\right)!}\varepsilon_{\phantom{j_{1}\ldots j_{n-k}}l_{1}\ldots l_{k}}^{j_{1}\ldots j_{n-k}}\varepsilon_{\phantom{i_{1}\ldots i_{k}}i_{k+1}\ldots i_{n}}^{i_{1}\ldots i_{k}}\omega_{i_{1}\ldots i_{k}}\dd x^{l_{1}}\wedge\ldots\wedge\dd x^{l_{k}}=\\
 & =\frac{1}{k!\left(n-k\right)!}g_{l_{1}r_{1}}\ldots g_{l_{k}r_{k}}\varepsilon^{j_{1}\ldots j_{n-k},r_{1}\ldots r_{k}}g^{s_{1}i_{1}}\ldots g^{s_{k}i_{k}}\varepsilon_{s_{1}\ldots s_{k},i_{k+1}\ldots i_{n}}\omega_{i_{1}\ldots i_{k}}\dd x^{l_{1}}\wedge\ldots\wedge\dd x^{l_{k}}=\\
 & =\frac{\left(-1\right)^{k\left(n-k\right)}}{k!\left(n-k\right)!}g_{l_{1}r_{1}}\ldots g_{l_{k}r_{k}}g^{s_{1}i_{1}}\ldots g^{s_{k}i_{k}}\varepsilon^{j_{1}\ldots j_{n-k},r_{1}\ldots r_{k}}\varepsilon_{s_{1}\ldots s_{k},i_{k+1}\ldots i_{n}}\omega_{i_{1}\ldots i_{k}}\dd x^{l_{1}}\wedge\ldots\wedge\dd x^{l_{k}}
\end{align*}
Beachte:
\begin{align*}
\varepsilon^{i_{1}\ldots i_{n}} & =g^{i_{1}j_{1}}\ldots g^{i_{n}j_{n}}\varepsilon_{j_{1}\ldots j_{n}}=g^{i_{1}j_{1}}\ldots g^{i_{n}j_{n}}\sqrt{\det\left(g\right)}\epsilon_{j_{1}\ldots j_{n}}=\\
 & =\det\left(g^{-1}\right)\sqrt{\det\left(g\right)}\epsilon_{j_{1}\ldots j_{n}}=\frac{\sqrt{\det\left(g\right)}}{\det\left(g\right)}\epsilon_{j_{1}\ldots j_{n}}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{\det\left(g\right)}}\epsilon_{j_{1}\ldots j_{n}}
\end{align*}
Damit folgt:
\begin{align*}
**\omega & =\frac{\left(-1\right)^{k\left(n-k\right)}}{k!\left(n-k\right)!}g_{l_{1}r_{1}}\ldots g_{l_{k}r_{k}}g^{s_{1}i_{1}}\ldots g^{s_{k}i_{k}}\epsilon^{j_{1}\ldots j_{n-k},r_{1}\ldots r_{k}}\epsilon_{s_{1}\ldots s_{k},i_{k+1}\ldots i_{n}}\omega_{i_{1}\ldots i_{k}}\dd x^{l_{1}}\wedge\ldots\wedge\dd x^{l_{k}}
\end{align*}
Klar ist, dass man nur Beiträge bekommt, wenn $\left(s_{1},\ldots,s_{k}\right)$
eine Permutation von $\left(r_{1},\ldots,r_{k}\right)$ ist. Wegen
der Antisymmetrie des Dachprodukts und der Komponenten $\omega_{i_{1},\ldots,i_{k}}$
folgt schließlich:
\begin{align*}
**\omega & =\left(-1\right)^{k\left(n-k\right)}g_{l_{1}r_{1}}g^{r_{1}i_{1}}\ldots g_{l_{k}r_{k}}g^{r_{k}i_{k}}\omega_{i_{1}\ldots i_{k}}\dd x^{l_{1}}\wedge\ldots\wedge\dd x^{l_{k}}=\\
 & =\left(-1\right)^{k\left(n-k\right)}\omega_{i_{1}\ldots i_{k}}\dd x^{l_{1}}\wedge\ldots\wedge\dd x^{l_{k}}=\left(-1\right)^{k\left(n-k\right)}\omega
\end{align*}
\qqed

Mit Hilfe des Hodge-Sterns kann man nun ein Skalarprodukt auf $\Omega^{k}\left(M\right)$
einführen:
\begin{align*}
\left\langle .,.\right\rangle :\Omega^{k}\left(M\right)\times\Omega^{k}\left(M\right) & \to\mathbb{R}\\
\left(\omega,\eta\right) & \mapsto\int_{M}\left(\omega\wedge\left(*\eta\right)\right)
\end{align*}



\subsection{Lemma}

Für jede $n$-Form $\omega\in\Omega^{n}\left(M\right)$ gilt:
\begin{align*}
\int_{M}\omega & =\int_{M}\left(*\omega\right)\dd\mu_{M}
\end{align*}



\subsubsection*{Beweis}

\begin{align*}
*^{2}\big|_{\Omega^{n}\left(M\right)} & =\mathbbm{1}
\end{align*}
Es ist
\begin{align*}
*\omega & =:f
\end{align*}
eine skalare Funktion.
\begin{align*}
\omega & =*f=f\varepsilon=f\sqrt{\det\left(g\right)}\dd x^{1}\wedge\ldots\wedge\dd x^{n}
\end{align*}
\qqed


\subsection{Lemma}

Die Bilinearform auf $\Omega^{k}\left(M\right)$, $\left\langle \omega,\eta\right\rangle =\int_{M}\left(\omega\wedge\left(*\eta\right)\right)$
ist symmetrisch und positiv definit.


\subsubsection*{Beweis}

\begin{align*}
\left\langle \omega,\eta\right\rangle  & \stackrel{\ref{a}6.6.3}{=}\int_{M}*\left(\omega\wedge\left(*\eta\right)\right)\dd\mu_{M}\\
*\left(\omega\wedge\left(*\eta\right)\right) & =\varepsilon^{i_{1}\ldots i_{n}}\left(\omega_{i_{1}\ldots i_{k}}\left(*\eta\right)_{i_{k+1}\ldots i_{n}}\right)=\\
 & =\frac{1}{k!}\varepsilon^{i_{1}\ldots i_{n}}\omega_{i_{1}\ldots i_{k}}\varepsilon_{j_{1}\ldots j_{k},i_{k+1}\ldots i_{n}}\eta^{j_{1}\ldots j_{k}}=\\
 & =\frac{\left(n-k\right)!}{k!}\left(*\omega\right)^{i_{1}\ldots i_{n-k}}\left(*\eta\right)_{i_{1}\ldots i_{n-k}}
\end{align*}
Offenbar ist dies symmetrisch und positiv definit.\qqed


\subsection{Lemma}

Die Adjungierte von $\dd$ bezüglich $\left\langle .,.\right\rangle $
ist:
\begin{align*}
\dd^{*} & =\left(-1\right)^{k\left(n-k+1\right)}*\dd*:\Omega^{k}\left(M\right)\to\Omega^{k-1}\left(M\right)
\end{align*}



\subsubsection*{Beweis}

Sei $\omega\in\Omega^{k-1}\left(M\right)$ und $\eta\in\Omega^{k}\left(M\right)$.
Dann gilt:
\begin{align*}
\left\langle \dd\omega,\eta\right\rangle  & =\int_{M}\left(\dd\omega\right)\wedge\left(*\eta\right)\sr ={\text{Produktregel}}{}\underbrace{\int_{M}\dd\left(\omega\wedge*\eta\right)}_{=0}+\left(-1\right)^{k}\int_{M}\omega\wedge\dd*\eta=\\
 & \sr ={\text{Stokes}}{}\left(-1\right)^{k}\int_{M}\omega\wedge\dd*\eta=\left(-1\right)^{k\left(n-k+1\right)}\int_{M}\omega\wedge*\left(*\dd*\eta\right)=\left(-1\right)^{k\left(n-k+1\right)}\left\langle \omega,*\dd*\eta\right\rangle 
\end{align*}
\qqed

Mit diesen Vorbereitungen kann man schließlich Operatoren zweiter
Ordnung einführen, den Hodge-Laplace-Operator:
\begin{align*}
\Delta & :=-\left(\dd\dd^{*}+\dd^{*}\dd\right):\Omega^{k}\left(M\right)\to\Omega^{k}\left(M\right)
\end{align*}
Auf 0-Formen ist:
\begin{align*}
\Delta f & =-\left(\dd\dd^{*}+\dd^{*}\dd\right)f=-\dd^{*}\dd f=\LB_{g}f
\end{align*}
Gerade wider der Laplace-Beltrami-Operator.

Der Laplace-Operator ist jetzt aber allgemein auf $k$-Formen definiert.
Er hat \emph{schöne} Eigenschaften.


\subsection{Lemma}

\begin{iiilist}

\iii 
\begin{align*}
\Delta\dd & =\dd\Delta\\
\dd^{*}\Delta & =\Delta^{*}\dd
\end{align*}


\iii $\left(-\Delta\right)$ ist positiv, also $\left\langle -\Delta\varphi,\varphi\right\rangle \ge0$
für alle $\varphi\in\Omega^{k}$.

\iii $\left\langle -\Delta\varphi,\varphi\right\rangle =0\quad\Leftrightarrow\quad\dd\varphi=0$
und $\dd^{*}\varphi=0$

\end{iiilist}


\subsubsection*{Beweis}

\begin{iiilist}

\iii

\begin{align*}
\Delta\dd & =-\left(\dd\dd^{*}+\dd^{*}\dd\right)\dd=-\dd\dd^{*}\dd=-\dd\left(\dd^{*}\dd+\dd\dd^{*}\right)=\dd\Delta
\end{align*}
$\Delta\dd^{*}=\dd^{*}\Delta$ folgt genauso, wenn man zusätzlich
verwendet:
\begin{align*}
0 & =\left(\dd\circ\dd\right)^{*}=\dd^{*}\circ\dd^{*}=\left(\dd^{*}\right)^{2}
\end{align*}


\iii Es gilt:
\begin{align*}
\left\langle -\Delta\varphi,\varphi\right\rangle  & =\left\langle \dd\dd^{*}\varphi+\dd^{*}\dd\varphi,\varphi\right\rangle =\left\langle \dd^{*}\varphi,\dd^{*}\varphi\right\rangle +\left\langle \dd\varphi,\dd\varphi\right\rangle \ge0
\end{align*}


\iii $\left\langle -\Delta\varphi,\varphi\right\rangle =0$ gilt
genau dann, wenn beide Summanden verschwinden. Da $\left\langle ,\right\rangle $
positiv definit ist, folgt $\dd\varphi=0=\dd^{*}\varphi$

\end{iiilist}

\qqed

Ist $\Delta\varphi=0$, so heißt $\varphi$ \emph{harmonisch}.

Aus unserem Lemma folgt, dass dann $\dd\varphi=0=\dd^{*}\varphi$.
Jede harmonische Form ist also geschlossen.

Man kann also \emph{spezielle} geschlossene Formen konstruieren, indem
man harmonische Formen betrachtet. Damit lässt sich die deRham-Kohomologie
untersuchen. Dieses Gebiet heißt Harmonische Analysis.

Auf 0-Formen:
\begin{align*}
\dd^{*} & =*\dd*=0
\end{align*}


Denn $\dd$ verschwindet auf $n$-Formen. Also folgt
\begin{align*}
\Delta & =-\dd^{*}\dd
\end{align*}
und somit für $\omega\in\Omega^{0}\left(M\right)$:
\begin{align*}
\omega\text{ geschlossen} & \quad\Leftrightarrow\quad\omega\text{ harmonisch}
\end{align*}
Die exakten 0-Formen sind gerade die konstanten Formen.
\begin{align*}
0\to\mathbb{R}\stackrel{\dd}{\to}\Omega^{0}\left(M\right)\stackrel{\dd}{\to}\ldots
\end{align*}
Damit können wir die 0-te Kohomologie berechnen:


\subsection{Lemma}

$H^{0}\left(M\right)=0$


\subsubsection*{Beweis}

Nach Korollar \ref{a}5.2.3 ist jede harmonische Funktion konstant.
Also ist jede geschlossene $0$-Form exakt.\qqed

%DATE: Fr 13.7.12

Auf 1-Formen:

Sei $\varphi\in\Omega^{1}$ mit $\Delta\varphi=0$, man sagt dazu
$\varphi$ ist harmonisch. Es folgt:
\begin{align*}
\dd\varphi & =0 & \dd^{*}\varphi & =0
\end{align*}
Insbesondere ist $\varphi$ geschlossen.

Frage: Ist $\varphi$ auch exakt?

Bemerkung: Ist umgekehrt $\dd\varphi=0$, so folgt \emph{nicht}, dass
$\Delta\varphi=0$ ist, denn:
\begin{align*}
\Delta\varphi & =-\dd\dd^{*}\varphi-\dd^{*}\underbrace{\dd\varphi}_{=0}=-\dd\dd^{*}\varphi\stackrel{\text{i.A.}}{\not=}0
\end{align*}
Im allgemeinen kann $\dd^{*}\varphi\not=0$ sein.

Frage: Sei $\varphi\in\Omega^{1}$ mit $\dd\varphi=0$. Kann man $\varphi$
um eine exakte Form $\dd\eta$ abändern, sodass $\varphi+\dd\eta$
harmonisch ist.

Falls ja: In jeder Äquivalenzklasse in $H^{1}\left(M\right)$ gibt
es eine harmonische Form, oder äquivalent: Jede Vektor in $H^{1}\left(M\right)$
kann durch eine harmonische Form repräsentiert werden.


\subsection{Theorem \textmd{(Hodge-Theorem)}}

Zu jeder Äquivalenzklasse der de-Rham-Kohomologie $H^{k}\left(M\right)$
liegt genau eine harmonische Form.

\quotedblbase{}Beweisidee\textquotedblleft{}: Nehme an, $\varphi\in\Omega^{k}$
und $\dd\varphi=0$. Sei $\eta\in\Omega^{k-1}$.
\begin{align*}
\Delta\left(\varphi+\dd\eta\right) & =-\left(\dd\dd^{*}+\dd^{*}\dd\right)\left(\varphi+\dd\eta\right)=\\
 & =-\dd\dd^{*}\varphi-\dd^{*}\underbrace{\dd\varphi}_{=0}+\underbrace{\Delta\dd\eta}_{=\dd\left(\Delta\eta\right)}=\\
 & =\dd\left(-\dd^{*}\varphi+\Delta\eta\right)\stackrel{\text{?!}}{=}0
\end{align*}
Dies ist sicher erfüllt, wenn gilt:
\begin{align*}
\Delta\eta & =\dd^{*}\varphi &  & \text{Poisson-Gleichung}
\end{align*}
In der Theorie der partiellen Differentialgleichungen (SoSe 2013)
zeigt man, dass die Poisson-Gleichung für jedes $\dd^{*}\varphi$
eine glatte Lösung besitzt $\eta$. (elliptische Differentialgleichung)

Eindeutigkeit:

Seien $\alpha_{1}=\varphi+\dd\eta_{1}$ und $\alpha_{2}=\varphi+\dd\eta_{2}$
harmonisch.
\begin{align*}
\alpha_{1}-\alpha_{2} & =-\dd\underbrace{\left(\eta_{1}-\eta_{2}\right)}_{=:\beta}=-\dd\beta
\end{align*}
\begin{align*}
\left\langle \alpha_{1}-\alpha_{2},\dd\beta\right\rangle  & =\left\langle \dd^{*}\left(\alpha_{1}-\alpha_{2}\right),\beta\right\rangle =0
\end{align*}
Denn $\alpha_{1}-\alpha_{2}$ ist harmonisch und nach Lemma \ref{d}6.6.6
folgt:
\begin{align*}
\dd\left(\alpha_{1}-\alpha_{2}\right) & =0 & \dd^{*}\left(\alpha_{1}-\alpha_{2}\right) & =0
\end{align*}
Also:
\begin{align*}
-\left\langle \dd\beta,\dd\beta\right\rangle  & =0\\
\Rightarrow\quad\dd\beta & =0
\end{align*}


Also ist $\alpha_{1}=\alpha_{2}$.\qqed


\chapter{Distributionen und Fouriertransformation}

Literatur:
\begin{itemize}
\item \noun{J. Rauch}: \emph{Partial Differential Equations}, Anhang: \emph{A
crash course in distribution theory}
\item \noun{L. Schwartz}: \emph{Theory of Distributions}
\end{itemize}
Historisch: Dirac $\delta$-Distribution
\begin{align*}
\delta\left(x\right) & =0\quad\text{für }x\not=0\\
\int_{-\infty}^{\infty}\delta\left(x\right)\dd x & =1
\end{align*}
TODO: Abb1
\begin{align*}
\eta_{\varepsilon} & \xrightarrow{\varepsilon\to0}\delta
\end{align*}
Rechenregel:
\begin{align*}
\int_{-\infty}^{\infty}f\left(x\right)\delta\left(x\right)\dd x & =f\left(0\right)
\end{align*}
Eine Möglichkeit, dies mathematisch einzufüren ist das Dirac-Maß.

Aber wir möchten außerdem Distributionen und nicht-glatte Funktionen
differenzieren können. $\delta'\left(x\right)$ ist nicht als Maß
einführbar. Für $x\in\mathbb{R}^{n}$:
\begin{align*}
\Delta\frac{1}{\norm x}
\end{align*}


Idee: Werte im schwachen Sinn aus, rechne formal:
\begin{align*}
\int_{\mathbb{R}}\eta\left(x\right)\delta'\left(x\right)\dd x & \stackrel{\text{formal}}{=}-\int_{\mathbb{R}}\eta'\left(x\right)\delta\left(x\right)\dd x=-\eta'\left(0\right)
\end{align*}


Allgemein: $\eta\in S\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)$ Schwartz-Raum.
$S^{*}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)$ ist der Dualraum von $S\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)$.
\begin{align*}
S^{*}\ni\phi:S & \to\mathbb{R}\\
\left(\Delta\phi\right):S & \to\mathbb{R}\\
\left(\Delta\phi\right)\left(\eta\right) & :=\phi\underbrace{\left(\Delta\eta\right)}_{\in S}
\end{align*}
$S\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)$ ist unendlich-dimensional. Hier ist
unklar, was \emph{Stetigkeit} von $\phi\in S^{*}$ heißt.


\section{Definition}

Für $i_{1},\ldots,i_{k}\in\left\{ 1,\ldots,n\right\} $ ist der \emph{Multiindex}
$\alpha:=\left(i_{1},\ldots,i_{k}\right)$ ein geordnete Tupel von
Indizes und $\abs{\alpha}:=k$ die \emph{Stufe des Multiindex}.\\
Der Differentialoperator der Ordnung $k$.
\begin{align*}
\DD^{\alpha} & =\frac{\partial}{\partial x^{i_{1}}}\ldots\frac{\partial}{\partial x^{i_{k}}} &  & \text{Differentialoperator der Ordnung }k\\
x^{\alpha} & =x^{i_{1}}\ldots x^{i_{k}} &  & \text{Monom der Ordnung }k
\end{align*}
Sei $f\in C^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)$ und $r,s\in\mathbb{N}$.
\begin{align*}
\norm f_{r,s} & :=\sum_{\sr{}{\alpha\text{ mit}}{\abs{\alpha}\le r}}\sum_{\sr{}{\beta\text{ mit}}{\abs{\beta}\le s}}\sup_{x\in\mathbb{R}^{n}}\abs{x^{\alpha}\DD^{\beta}f\left(x\right)} &  & \text{Schwartz-Norm}\\
 & =\sup_{x}\abs{f\left(x\right)}+\sup\abs{\frac{\partial}{\partial x^{1}}f}+\sup\abs{x^{1}f}+\ldots
\end{align*}



\section{Definition}

Der \emph{Schwartz-Raum} $\mathscr{S}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)$
besteht aus allen $C^{\infty}$-Funktionen $f$, sodass $\norm f_{r,s}<\infty$
für alle $r,s\in\mathbb{N}$ ist.


\subsubsection*{Beispiel}

$f\left(x\right)=1$
\begin{align*}
\norm f_{1,0} & =\underbrace{\sup_{x}\abs{f\left(x\right)}}_{=1}+\sum_{i=1}^{n}\underbrace{\sup_{x}\abs{x^{i}f\left(x\right)}}_{=\infty}
\end{align*}
$f\left(x\right)=e^{-\norm x^{2}}$
\begin{align*}
\norm f_{r,0} & =\sum_{\abs{\alpha}\le r}\sup_{x}\abs{x^{\alpha}e^{-\norm x^{2}}}<\infty\\
\norm f_{r,s} & =\sum_{\abs{\alpha}\le r}\sum_{\abs{\beta}\le s}\sup\abs{\underbrace{x^{\alpha}\DD^{\beta}e^{-\norm x^{2}}}_{=P\left(x\right)e^{-\norm x^{2}}}}\stackrel{P\left(x\right)\text{ Polynom}}{=}\infty
\end{align*}
Es ist $C_{0}^{\infty}\subseteq\mathscr{S}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)$.
Man sagt auch, $\mathscr{S}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)$ sind die
glatten Funktionen mit \emph{schnellem Abfall} (engl.: rapid decay).


\subsubsection*{Topologie auf $\mathscr{S}$}

Eine Teilmenge $A\subseteq\mathscr{S}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)$
ist \emph{offen}, falls es zu jedem $f\in A$ ein $\varepsilon>0$
und $r,s\in\mathbb{N}$ gibt, sodass gilt:
\begin{align*}
B_{\varepsilon}^{r,s}\left(f\right) & :=\left\{ g\big|\norm{g-f}_{r,s}<\varepsilon\right\} \subseteq A
\end{align*}
Dies ist ähnlich wie in einem Banachraum, aber man hat jetzt eine
ganze Familie von Normen $\norm ._{r,s}$.

Allgemeiner: topologischer Vektorraum, uniformer Raum, $\ldots$

Konvergenzbegriff:

$f_{n}\to f$ in $\mathscr{S}$, falls in jeder offenen Umgebung von
$f$ fast alle $f_{n}$ liegen.


\section{Satz}

Eine Folge $\left(f_{n}\right)_{n\in\mathbb{N}}$ mit $f_{n}\in\mathscr{S}$
konvergiert gegen $f\in\mathscr{S}$ genau dann, wenn für alle $r,s\in\mathbb{N}$
schon $\norm{f-f_{n}}_{r,s}\xrightarrow{n\to\infty}0$ gilt.


\subsubsection*{Bemerkung}

Es gelte $f_{n}\to f$. Das heißt insbesondere gilt $\norm{f-f_{n}}_{0,0}\to0$,
also $\sup_{x\in\mathbb{R}^{n}}\abs{f_{n}\left(x\right)-f\left(x\right)}\to0$,
also $f_{n}\rightrightarrows f$. Außerdem gilt:
\begin{align*}
\norm{f-f_{n}}_{r,0} & \to0
\end{align*}
Also gilt $\sup_{x}\abs{\DD^{\alpha}f_{n}\left(x\right)-\DD^{\alpha}f\left(x\right)}\to0$
für alle $\alpha$, das heißt $\DD^{\alpha}f_{n}\rightrightarrows f$.
\begin{align*}
\norm{f-f_{n}}_{r,s} & \to0
\end{align*}
Also konvergiert $x^{\alpha}\DD^{\beta}f_{n}\rightrightarrows x^{\alpha}\DD^{\beta}f$
gleichmäßig.

Dies führt dazu, dass $\mathscr{S}$ vollständig ist.

%DATE: Di 17.7.12


\subsubsection*{Beweis}

\quotedblbase{}$\Rightarrow$\textquotedblleft{}: Die Konvergenz $f_{n}\xrightarrow{n\to\infty}f$
heißt nach Definition, dass in jeder offenen Umgebung von $f$ fast
alle $f_{n}$ liegen.

Also liegen für alle $r,s\in\mathbb{N}$ und jedes $\varepsilon\in\mathbb{R}_{>0}$
fast alle $f_{n}$ in $B_{\varepsilon}^{r,s}\left(f\right)$. Daher
konvergiert $\norm{f-f_{n}}_{r,s}\to0$.

\quotedblbase{}$\Leftarrow$\textquotedblleft{}: Nehme an, dass für
alle $r,s\in\mathbb{N}$ gilt:
\begin{align*}
\norm{f-f_{n}}_{r,s} & \xrightarrow{n\to\infty}0
\end{align*}
Sei $A$ eine offene Umgebung von $f$. Nach Definition der Topologie
auf $\mathscr{S}$ gibt es also $r,s\in\mathbb{N}$ und ein $\varepsilon\in\mathbb{R}_{>0}$
mit $B_{\varepsilon}^{r,s}\left(f\right)\subseteq A$.

Wegen $\norm{f_{n}-f}_{r,s}\to0$ folgt, dass fast alle $f_{n}$ in
$B_{\varepsilon}^{r,s}\left(f\right)$ liegen, und somit auch in $A$.\qqed


\section{Definition \textmd{(Distribution)}}

Sei $\mathscr{S}^{*}:=\left\{ T:\mathscr{S}\to\mathbb{R}\text{ linear und stetig}\right\} $
der Dualraum. $\mathscr{S}^{*}$ heißt der Raum der \emph{temperierten
Distributionen}.


\section{Satz\label{sec:Satz-StetigkeitDistribution}}

Ein lineares Funktional $T:\mathscr{S}\to\mathbb{R}$ ist genau dann
stetig, wenn es $r,s\in\mathbb{N}$ und ein $c\in\mathbb{R}_{>0}$
gibt, sodass gilt:
\begin{align}
\abs{Tf} & \le C\norm f_{r,s}\label{eq:Beschraenkt}
\end{align}



\subsubsection*{Beweis}

\quotedblbase{}$\Leftarrow$\textquotedblleft{}: Angenommen \eqref{eq:Beschraenkt}
gilt und $f_{n}\to f$ konvergiert in $\mathscr{S}$. Für die Stetigkeit
ist $Tf_{n}\to Tf$ zu zeigen. Es gilt:
\begin{align*}
\abs{Tf_{n}-Tf} & \stackrel{T\text{ linear}}{=}\abs{T\left(f_{n}-f\right)}\le C\norm{f_{n}-f}_{r,s}\xrightarrow{n\to\infty}0
\end{align*}
Denn sogar für alle $p,q\in\mathbb{N}$ konvergiert $\norm{f_{n}-f}_{p,q}\to0$.

Also bildet $T$ konvergente Folgen auf konvergente Folgen ab und
ist somit stetig.

\quotedblbase{}$\Rightarrow$\textquotedblright{}: Sei $T$ stetig.
Dann ist das Urbild offener Mengen offen. Also insbesondere für die
offene Menge $B_{1}\left(0\right)\subseteq\mathbb{R}$:
\begin{align*}
T^{-1}\left(B_{1}\left(0\right)\right) & \stackrel{\text{offen}}{\subseteq}\mathscr{S}
\end{align*}
Also gibt es $r,s\in\mathbb{N}$ und ein $\varepsilon\in\mathbb{R}_{>0}$
mit $B_{\varepsilon}^{r,s}\left(0\right)\subseteq T^{-1}\left(B_{1}\left(0\right)\right)$
oder äquivalent:
\begin{align*}
\norm f_{r,s}<\varepsilon & \quad\Rightarrow\quad\abs{Tf}<1
\end{align*}
Betrachte diese Ungleichung für $\tilde{f}=\lambda f$ mit $\lambda\in\mathbb{R}_{>0}$:
\begin{align*}
\norm f_{r,s}<\frac{\varepsilon}{\lambda} & \quad\Rightarrow\quad\abs{Tf}<\frac{1}{\lambda}
\end{align*}
Wähle nun zu gegebenem $f$ mit $\norm f_{r,s}\not=0$ (Sonst ist
die Behauptung klar, da $f=0$ folgt.) den Skalierungsfaktor ${\displaystyle \lambda:=\frac{\varepsilon}{\norm f_{r,s}}}$:
Aus
\begin{align*}
\norm f_{r,s} & <\frac{2\varepsilon}{\varepsilon}\norm f_{r,s}
\end{align*}
folgt dann:
\begin{align*}
\abs{Tf} & <\frac{2}{\varepsilon}\norm f_{r,s}
\end{align*}
Also gilt für alle $f\in\mathscr{S}$:
\begin{align*}
\abs{Tf} & \le\frac{2}{\varepsilon}\norm f_{r,s}
\end{align*}
\qqed


\section{Beispiele \textmd{($\delta$-Distribution)}}

$\delta\in\mathscr{S}^{*}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)$ soll eingeführt
werden. Die Abbildung
\begin{align*}
\delta:\mathscr{S} & \to\mathbb{R}\\
f & \mapsto f\left(0\right)
\end{align*}
ist linear. Um zu zeigen, dass $\delta$ stetig ist, müssen wir zeigen,
dass es geeignete $r,s\in\mathbb{N}$ und $C\in\mathbb{R}_{>0}$ mit
$\abs{\delta\left(f\right)}\le C\abs f_{r,s}$ gibt:
\begin{align*}
\abs{\delta\left(f\right)} & =\abs{f\left(0\right)}\le\sup_{x\in\mathbb{R}^{n}}\abs{f\left(x\right)}=\norm f_{0,0}
\end{align*}
Nützliche Notation:
\begin{align*}
\delta\left(f\right) & =:\int_{\mathbb{R}^{n}}f\left(x\right)\delta\left(x\right)\dd^{n}x
\end{align*}



\section{Beispiel \textmd{(Integraloperator)}}

\begin{abclist}

\abc Sei $g\in C^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)$ mit höchstens
polynomialem Anstieg, das heißt, es gibt $r,C\in\mathbb{R}_{>0}$
mit:
\begin{align*}
\abs{g\left(x\right)} & \le\left(1+\norm x^{r}\right)
\end{align*}
\begin{align*}
T_{g}:\mathscr{S}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right) & \to\mathbb{R}\\
f & \mapsto\int_{\mathbb{R}^{n}}f\left(x\right)g\left(x\right)\dd^{n}x
\end{align*}
Dieses Integral ist endlich:
\begin{align*}
\abs{T_{g}f} & \le\int_{\mathbb{R}}\abs{f\left(x\right)}\cdot\underbrace{\abs{g\left(x\right)}}_{\le C\left(1+\norm x^{r}\right)}\dd^{n}x\le C\left(1+\norm x^{r}\right)
\end{align*}
Da $f\in\mathscr{S}$ gilt, folgt:
\begin{align*}
\infty> & \underbrace{\norm f_{0,0}+\norm f_{r+n+1,0}}_{=:K}=\sup_{x}\left(\abs{f\left(x\right)}\right)+\sup_{x}\abs{\norm x^{r+n++1}f\left(x\right)}\ge\sup\left(\left(1+\norm x^{r+n+1}\right)f\left(x\right)\right)
\end{align*}
\begin{align*}
\Rightarrow\quad\abs{f\left(x\right)}\left(1+\norm x^{r+n+1}\right) & \le K\\
\abs{f\left(x\right)} & \le\frac{K}{1+\norm x^{r+n+1}}\\
\Rightarrow\quad\abs{T_{g}f} & \le\int_{\mathbb{R}^{n}}\frac{a\left(1+\norm x^{r}\right)}{1+\norm x^{r+n+1}}\dd^{n}x\le\int_{\mathbb{R}^{n}}\frac{\tilde{a}}{1+\norm x^{n+1}}<b
\end{align*}
$T_{g}f$ ist stetig:
\begin{align*}
\abs{T_{g}f} & \le\int_{\mathbb{R}^{n}}\frac{C}{1+\norm x^{n+1}}\left(\norm f_{0,0}+\norm f_{r+n+1,0}\right)\le\tilde{a}\norm f_{r+n+1,0}
\end{align*}
Denn $\norm f_{p,q}\le\norm f_{r,s}$ für alle $p\le r$ und $g\le s$.

Auf diese Weise kann man $g$ eine Distribution $T_{g}$ zuordnen.
Oft wird $g$ mit $T_{g}$ identifiziert. Damit werden Distributionen
zu verallgemeinern.

\abc $g=e^{x}$:
\begin{align*}
T_{g}f:\mathscr{S}\left(\mathbb{R}\right) & \to\mathbb{R}\\
f & \mapsto\int_{\mathbb{R}^{n}}f\cdot g\dd^{n}x
\end{align*}
ist \emph{nicht} wohldefiniert, denn zum Beispiel ${\displaystyle f=\frac{1}{\cosh\left(x\right)}}$
fällt exponentiell im Unendlichen ab und somit ist $f\in\mathscr{S}$,
aber es gilt:
\begin{align*}
\int_{\mathbb{R}}\frac{e^{x}}{\cosh\left(x\right)}\dd x & =+\infty
\end{align*}
\begin{align*}
\lim_{x\to\infty}\frac{e^{x}}{\cosh\left(x\right)} & =2
\end{align*}
Also ist $T_{g}$ keine temperierte Distribution.

\end{abclist}


\section{Beispiel \textmd{(Ableitung der $\delta$-Distribution)}}

Was ist die Ableitung $\delta'$?

Rechne erst formal für ein $f\in\mathscr{S}$:
\begin{align*}
\int_{\mathbb{R}}\delta'\left(x\right)f\left(x\right)\dd x & \stackrel{\text{part.Int.}}{=}-\int_{\mathbb{R}}\delta\left(x\right)f'\left(x\right)\dd x=-f'\left(0\right)
\end{align*}
Das Ergebnis dieser formalen Rechnung verwenden wir jetzt als Definition:
\begin{align*}
\delta':\mathscr{S} & \to\mathbb{R}\\
f & \mapsto-f^{'}\left(0\right)
\end{align*}
ist eine lineare Abbildung, also ist $\delta'$ stetig und somit $\delta'\in\mathscr{S}^{*}$.
\begin{align*}
\abs{\delta'\left(f\right)} & \le\sup_{x\in\mathbb{R}}\abs{f'\left(x\right)}\le\sup_{x\in\mathbb{R}}\abs{f\left(x\right)}+\sup_{x\in\mathbb{R}}\abs{f'\left(x\right)}=\norm f_{0,1}
\end{align*}



\section{Definition \textmd{(Distributionsableitung)}}

Sei $T\in\mathscr{S}^{*}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)$ und $\alpha$
ein Multi-Index. Definiere die Distributionsabbildung $\DD^{\alpha}T$
durch:
\begin{align*}
\left(\DD^{\alpha}T\right)\left(f\right) & :=\left(-1\right)^{\abs{\alpha}}T\left(\DD^{\alpha}f\right)
\end{align*}



\subsubsection*{Behauptung}

$\DD^{\alpha}T\in\mathscr{S}^{*}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)$ ist
also eine temperiere Distribution.


\subsubsection*{Beweis}

Aus $T\in\mathscr{S}^{*}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)$ folgt für alle
$f\in\mathscr{S}$:
\begin{align*}
\norm{Tf} & \le C\norm f_{r,s}
\end{align*}
\begin{align*}
\abs{\left(\DD^{\alpha}T\right)\left(f\right)} & =\abs{T\left(\DD^{\alpha}f\right)}\le C\norm{\DD^{\alpha}f}_{r,s}\le C\norm f_{r,s+\abs{\alpha}}
\end{align*}
Also ist $\DD^{\alpha}T$ stetig nach Satz \eqref{sec:Satz-StetigkeitDistribution}.\qqed

Es gilt noch Folgendes (ohne Beweis):


\section{Satz}

Für $g\in C^{\infty}$ mit höchstens polynomialem Anstieg ist die
Abbildung $g\mapsto T_{g}\in\mathscr{S}^{*}$ ist injektiv.

Allgemeiner $g\in\hat{L}_{\text{loc}}$.


\section{Lemma}

Es gilt
\begin{align*}
\norm{f\cdot g}_{r,s} & \le\norm f_{r,s}\cdot\norm g_{r,s}
\end{align*}
und sogar noch bessere Ungleichungen.

which means that derivative works of the document must themselves
be free in the same sense. It complements the GNU General Public License,
which is a copyleft license designed for free software.

\noindent We have designed this License in order to use it for manuals
for free software, because free software needs free documentation:
a free program should come with manuals providing the same freedoms
that the software does. But this License is not limited to software
manuals; it can be used for any textual work, regardless of subject

A \textquotedblleft{}\textbf{Modified Version}\textquotedblright{}
of the Document means any work containing the Document or a portion

into another language.

A \textquotedblleft{}\textbf{Secondary Section}\textquotedblright{}
is a named appendix or a front-matter section of the Document that
deals exclusively with the relationship of the publishers or authors
of the Document to the Document's overall subject (or to related matters)
and contains nothing that could fall directly within that overall
subject. (Thus, if the Document is in part a textbook of mathematics,
a Secondary Section may not explain any mathematics.) The relationship
could be a matter of historical connection with the subject or with

political position regarding them.

The \textquotedblleft{}\textbf{Invariant Sections}\textquotedblright{}
are certain Secondary Sections whose titles are designated, as being

The \textquotedblleft{}\textbf{Cover Texts}\textquotedblright{} are
certain short passages of text that are listed, as Front-Cover Texts
or Back-Cover Texts, in the notice that says that the Document is
released under this License. A Front-Cover Text may be at most 5 words,
and a Back-Cover Text may be at most 25 words.

A \textquotedblleft{}\textbf{Transparent}\textquotedblright{} copy
of the Document means a machine-readable copy, represented in a format
whose specification is available to the general public, that is suitable
for revising the document straightforwardly with generic text editors
or (for images composed of pixels) generic paint programs or (for
drawings) some widely available drawing editor, and that is suitable
for input to text formatters or for automatic translation to a variety
of formats suitable for input to text formatters. A copy made in an
otherwise Transparent file format whose markup, or absence of markup,
has been arranged to thwart or discourage subsequent modification
by readers is not Transparent. An image format is not Transparent
if used for any substantial amount of text. A copy that is not \textquotedblleft{}Transparent\textquotedblright{}
is called \textquotedblleft{}\textbf{Opaque}\textquotedblright{}.

Examples of suitable formats for Transparent copies include plain
ASCII without markup, Texinfo input format, \LaTeX{} input format,
SGML or XML using a publicly available DTD, and standard-conforming
simple HTML, PostScript or PDF designed for human modification. Examples
of transparent image formats include PNG, XCF and JPG. Opaque formats
include proprietary formats that can be read and edited only by proprietary
word processors, SGML or XML for which the DTD and/or processing tools
are not generally available, and the machine-generated HTML, PostScript
or PDF produced by some word processors for output purposes only.

The \textquotedblleft{}\textbf{Title Page}\textquotedblright{} means,
for a printed book, the title page itself, plus such following pages
as are needed to hold, legibly, the material this License requires
to appear in the title page. For works in formats which do not have
any title page as such, \textquotedblleft{}Title Page\textquotedblright{}
means the text near the most prominent appearance of the work's title,
preceding the beginning of the body of the text.

The \textquotedblleft{}\textbf{publisher}\textquotedblright{} means
any person or entity that distributes copies of the Document to the
public.

A section \textquotedblleft{}\textbf{Entitled XYZ}\textquotedblright{}
means a named subunit of the Document whose title either is precisely

or \textquotedblleft{}\textbf{History}\textquotedblright{}.) To \textquotedblleft{}\textbf{Preserve
the Title}\textquotedblright{} of such a section when you modify the

\section*{\noun{5. Combining documents}}

You may combine the Document with other documents released under this
License, under the terms defined in section 4 above for modified versions,
provided that you include in the combination all of the Invariant
Sections of all of the original documents, unmodified, and list them
all as Invariant Sections of your combined work in its license notice,
and that you preserve all their Warranty Disclaimers.

The combined work need only contain one copy of this License, and
multiple identical Invariant Sections may be replaced with a single
copy. If there are multiple Invariant Sections with the same name
but different contents, make the title of each such section unique
by adding at the end of it, in parentheses, the name of the original
author or publisher of that section if known, or else a unique number.
Make the same adjustment to the section titles in the list of Invariant
Sections in the license notice of the combined work.

In the combination, you must combine any sections Entitled \textquotedblleft{}History\textquotedblright{}
in the various original documents, forming one section Entitled \textquotedblleft{}History\textquotedblright{};
likewise combine any sections Entitled \textquotedblleft{}Acknowledgements\textquotedblright{},
and any sections Entitled \textquotedblleft{}Dedications\textquotedblright{}.
You must delete all sections Entitled \textquotedblleft{}Endorsements\textquotedblright{}.


\section*{\noun{6. Collections of documents}}

You may make a collection consisting of the Document and other documents
released under this License, and replace the individual copies of
this License in the various documents with a single copy that is included
in the collection, provided that you follow the rules of this License
for verbatim copying of each of the documents in all other respects.

You may extract a single document from such a collection, and distribute
it individually under this License, provided you insert a copy of
this License into the extracted document, and follow this License
in all other respects regarding verbatim copying of that document.


\section*{\noun{7. Aggregation with independent works}}

A compilation of the Document or its derivatives with other separate
and independent documents or works, in or on a volume of a storage
or distribution medium, is called an \textquotedblleft{}aggregate\textquotedblright{}
if the copyright resulting from the compilation is not used to limit
the legal rights of the compilation's users beyond what the individual
works permit. When the Document is included in an aggregate, this
License does not apply to the other works in the aggregate which are
not themselves derivative works of the Document.

If the Cover Text requirement of section 3 is applicable to these
copies of the Document, then if the Document is less than one half
of the entire aggregate, the Document's Cover Texts may be placed
on covers that bracket the Document within the aggregate, or the electronic
equivalent of covers if the Document is in electronic form. Otherwise
they must appear on printed covers that bracket the whole aggregate.


\section*{\noun{8. Translation}}

Translation is considered a kind of modification, so you may distribute
translations of the Document under the terms of section 4. Replacing
Invariant Sections with translations requires special permission from
their copyright holders, but you may include translations of some
or all Invariant Sections in addition to the original versions of
these Invariant Sections. You may include a translation of this License,
and all the license notices in the Document, and any Warranty Disclaimers,
provided that you also include the original English version of this
License and the original versions of those notices and disclaimers.
In case of a disagreement between the translation and the original
version of this License or a notice or disclaimer, the original version
will prevail.

If a section in the Document is Entitled \textquotedblleft{}Acknowledgements\textquotedblright{},
\textquotedblleft{}Dedications\textquotedblright{}, or \textquotedblleft{}History\textquotedblright{},
the requirement (section 4) to Preserve its Title (section 1) will
typically require changing the actual title.


\section*{\noun{9. Termination}}

You may not copy, modify, sublicense, or distribute the Document except
as expressly provided under this License. Any attempt otherwise to
copy, modify, sublicense, or distribute it is void, and will automatically
terminate your rights under this License.

However, if you cease all violation of this License, then your license
from a particular copyright holder is reinstated (a) provisionally,
unless and until the copyright holder explicitly and finally terminates
your license, and (b) permanently, if the copyright holder fails to
notify you of the violation by some reasonable means prior to 60 days
after the cessation.

Moreover, your license from a particular copyright holder is reinstated
permanently if the copyright holder notifies you of the violation
by some reasonable means, this is the first time you have received
notice of violation of this License (for any work) from that copyright
holder, and you cure the violation prior to 30 days after your receipt
of the notice.

Termination of your rights under this section does not terminate the
licenses of parties who have received copies or rights from you under
this License. If your rights have been terminated and not permanently
reinstated, receipt of a copy of some or all of the same material
does not give you any rights to use it.


\section*{\noun{10. Future revisions of this license}}

The Free Software Foundation may publish new, revised versions of
the GNU Free Documentation License from time to time. Such new versions
will be similar in spirit to the present version, but may differ in
detail to address new problems or concerns. See \url{https://www.gnu.org/copyleft/}.

Each version of the License is given a distinguishing version number.
If the Document specifies that a particular numbered version of this
License \textquotedbl{}or any later version\textquotedbl{} applies
to it, you have the option of following the terms and conditions either
of that specified version or of any later version that has been published
(not as a draft) by the Free Software Foundation. If the Document
does not specify a version number of this License, you may choose
any version ever published (not as a draft) by the Free Software Foundation.
If the Document specifies that a proxy can decide which future versions
of this License can be used, that proxy's public statement of acceptance
of a version permanently authorizes you to choose that version for
the Document.


\section*{\noun{11. Relicensing}}

\textquotedblleft{}Massive Multiauthor Collaboration Site\textquotedblright{}
(or \textquotedblleft{}MMC Site\textquotedblright{}) means any World
Wide Web server that publishes copyrightable works and also provides
prominent facilities for anybody to edit those works. A public wiki
that anybody can edit is an example of such a server. A \textquotedblleft{}Massive
Multiauthor Collaboration\textquotedblright{} (or \textquotedblleft{}MMC\textquotedblright{})
contained in the site means any set of copyrightable works thus published
on the MMC site.

\textquotedblleft{}CC-BY-SA\textquotedblright{} means the Creative
Commons Attribution-Share Alike 3.0 license published by Creative
Commons Corporation, a not-for-profit corporation with a principal
place of business in San Francisco, California, as well as future
copyleft versions of that license published by that same organization.

\textquotedblleft{}Incorporate\textquotedblright{} means to publish
or republish a Document, in whole or in part, as part of another Document.

An MMC is \textquotedblleft{}eligible for relicensing\textquotedblright{}
if it is licensed under this License, and if all works that were first
published under this License somewhere other than this MMC, and subsequently
incorporated in whole or in part into the MMC, (1) had no cover texts
or invariant sections, and (2) were thus incorporated prior to November
1, 2008.

The operator of an MMC Site may republish an MMC contained in the
site under CC-BY-SA on the same site at any time before August 1,
2009, provided the MMC is eligible for relicensing.


\section*{\noun{Addendum}: How to use this License for your documents}

To use this License in a document you have written, include a copy
of the License in the document and put the following copyright and
license notices just after the title page:
\begin{quote}
Copyright © YEAR YOUR NAME.\\
Permission is granted to copy, distribute and/or modify this document
under the terms of the GNU Free Documentation License, Version 1.3
or any later version published by the Free Software Foundation;

with no Invariant Sections, no Front-Cover Texts, and no Back-Cover
Texts.

A copy of the license is included in the section entitled \textquotedbl{}GNU
Free Documentation License\textquotedbl{}.
\end{quote}
If you have Invariant Sections, Front-Cover Texts and Back-Cover Texts,
replace the \textquotedbl{}with $\ldots$ Texts.\textquotedbl{} line
with this:
\begin{quote}
with the Invariant Sections being LIST THEIR TITLES, with the Front-Cover
Texts being LIST, and with the Back-Cover Texts being LIST.
\end{quote}
If you have Invariant Sections without Cover Texts, or some other
combination of the three, merge those two alternatives to suit the
situation.

If your document contains nontrivial examples of program code, we
recommend releasing these examples in parallel under your choice of
free software license, such as the GNU General Public License, to
permit their use in free software.
